Tomic and Nick Kyrgios were warned by Australia&#039;s Olympic chef de mission Kitty Chiller at the weekend that they were among a group of athletes whose behaviour was being monitored to judge their suitability for the Rio team. &quot;With a heavy sense of regret, I have made the difficult decision to not play with the Australian tennis team as they pursue an Olympic medal in Rio,&quot; Tomic said in a statement.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>https://in.news.yahoo.com/tomic-too-busy-represent-australia-rio-053932007--ten.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 11:09:32 +0530</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">tomic-too-busy-represent-australia-rio-053932007--ten</guid><media:content url="https://s1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/yf6Aon0Nwtr75ZrEBpyqDg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-12T235713Z_1_LYNXNPEC4B1U0_RTROPTP_2_TENNIS-OPEN.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="https://in.news.yahoo.com/tomic-too-busy-represent-australia-rio-053932007--ten.html"><img src="https://s1.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/yf6Aon0Nwtr75ZrEBpyqDg--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-12T235713Z_1_LYNXNPEC4B1U0_RTROPTP_2_TENNIS-OPEN.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="Australia&#039;s Tomic hits a shot during his third round match against compatriot Millman at the Australian Open tennis tournament at Melbourne Park" align="left" title="Australia&#039;s Tomic hits a shot during his third round match against compatriot Millman at the Australian Open tennis tournament at Melbourne Park" border="0" /></a>Australia&#039;s Bernard Tomic ruled himself out of consideration for the Rio Olympics on Friday due to an &quot;extremely busy&quot; playing schedule, with the world number 22 saying he would play an ATP tournament in Mexico instead. Tomic and Nick Kyrgios were warned by Australia&#039;s Olympic chef de mission Kitty Chiller at the weekend that they were among a group of athletes whose behaviour was being monitored to judge their href="https://in.news.yahoo.com/doping-program-behind-russian-medals-sochi-olympics-report-024911089--spt.html"><img src="https://s.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/6OnPvVv60R8PwZnh13M01g--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-13T024911Z_2_LYNXNPEC4B1I1_RTROPTP_2_RUSSIA.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="Employee arranges medals for the 2014 Winter Olympic Games during a presentation for the public at a jewellery shop in St. Petersburg" align="left" title="Employee arranges medals for the 2014 Winter Olympic Games during a presentation for the public at a jewellery shop in St. Petersburg" border="0" /></a>By Reuters Staff Dozens of Russian athletes who competed at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics, including at least 15 medal winners, were part of a state-run doping program, the New York Times reported on Thursday. The report is broadly consistent with revelations by an independent World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) commission last November of widespread state-sponsored doping in Russia, which led to a ban on the country competing in international athletics competitions. According to the New York Times report, which is based largely on evidence from Grigory Rodchenkov, the director of the country&#039;s anti-doping laboratory during the Sochi Olympics, those involved included some of Russia’s biggest stars of the Games, including 14 members of its cross-country ski team and two veteran bobsledders who won two golds.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>https://in.news.yahoo.com/doping-program-behind-russian-medals-sochi-olympics-report-024911089--spt.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 08:19:11 +0530</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">doping-program-behind-russian-medals-sochi-olympics-report-024911089--spt</guid><media:content url="https://s.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/6OnPvVv60R8PwZnh13M01g--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-13T024911Z_2_LYNXNPEC4B1I1_RTROPTP_2_RUSSIA.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="https://in.news.yahoo.com/doping-program-behind-russian-medals-sochi-olympics-report-024911089--spt.html"><img src="https://s.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/6OnPvVv60R8PwZnh13M01g--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-13T024911Z_2_LYNXNPEC4B1I1_RTROPTP_2_RUSSIA.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="Employee arranges medals for the 2014 Winter Olympic Games during a presentation for the public at a jewellery shop in St. Petersburg" align="left" title="Employee arranges medals for the 2014 Winter Olympic Games during a presentation for the public at a jewellery shop in St. Petersburg" border="0" /></a>By Reuters Staff Dozens of Russian athletes who competed at the 2014 Sochi Winter Olympics, including at least 15 medal winners, were part of a state-run doping program, the New York Times reported on Thursday. The report is broadly consistent with revelations by an independent World Anti-Doping Agency (WADA) commission last November of widespread state-sponsored doping in Russia, which led to a ban on the country competing in international athletics competitions. According to the New York Times report, which is based largely on evidence from Grigory Rodchenkov, the director of the country&#039;s anti-doping laboratory during the Sochi Olympics, those involved included some of Russia’s biggest stars of the Games, including 14 members of its cross-country ski team and two veteran bobsledders who won two golds.</p><br clear="all"/></media:text><media:credit role="publishing company"></media:credit></item><item><title>Russian team Rostov subjected to random doping test - FIFA</title><description>Russian Premier League side Rostov had their entire team subjected to a random doping test following their match against Dinamo Moscow on Thursday, FIFA said. FIFA, confirming a report by Russia's Tass news agency, said the test was routine and there were no complaints from players or officials. Rostov, second in the league and two points behind CSKA Moscow, won the match 3-1.</description><link>https://in.news.yahoo.com/russian-team-rostov-subjected-random-doping-test-fifa-010114328--sow.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 08:19:11 +0530</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">russian-team-rostov-subjected-random-doping-test-fifa-010114328--sow</guid></item><item><title>WADA may ask IOC to retest Russian Sochi doping samples</title><description>WADA's incoming director general said on Thursday he'd consider asking the International Olympic Committee to retest samples of Russian athletes from the Sochi Games, following allegations of systemic doping in that country. Olivier Niggli said the World Anti-Doping Agency would investigate allegations made by the former director of Russia's anti-doping lab in the New York Times, and could ask the IOC to retest samples if it deems the information useful. While the cost of retesting could limit WADA's ability to probe frozen athletes' samples from the 2014 Sochi Olympics, athletes have called for action in the wake of the Russian allegations.</description><link>https://in.news.yahoo.com/wada-may-ask-ioc-retest-russian-sochi-doping-024911072--spt.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 08:19:11 +0530</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">wada-may-ask-ioc-retest-russian-sochi-doping-024911072--spt</guid></item><item><title>Welbeck is 'gutted' to miss Euro 2016 - Temer, a 75-year-old centrist now moving to steer Latin America&#039;s biggest country towards more market-friendly policies, told Brazilians to have &quot;confidence&quot; they would overcome an ongoing crisis sparked by a deep economic recession, political volatility and a sprawling corruption scandal. &quot;It is urgent we calm the nation and unite Brazil,&quot; he said, after a signing ceremony for his incoming cabinet.</p><br clear="all"/></description><link>https://in.news.yahoo.com/brazils-temer-calls-unity-confidence-brazil-recovery-012224007--business.html</link><pubDate>Fri, 13 May 2016 06:52:24 +0530</pubDate><source url="http://www.reuters.com/">Reuters</source><guid isPermaLink="false">brazils-temer-calls-unity-confidence-brazil-recovery-012224007--business</guid><media:content url="https://s.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/89tMBsSgGGLC.wu_dSeqRA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-13T005444Z_1_LYNXNPEC4C01J_RTROPTP_2_BRAZIL-POLITICS.JPG" type="image/jpeg" width="130" height="86"></media:content><media:text type="html"><p><a href="https://in.news.yahoo.com/brazils-temer-calls-unity-confidence-brazil-recovery-012224007--business.html"><img src="https://s.yimg.com/bt/api/res/1.2/89tMBsSgGGLC.wu_dSeqRA--/YXBwaWQ9eW5ld3NfbGVnbztmaT1maWxsO2g9ODY7cT03NTt3PTEzMA--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_us/News/Reuters/2016-05-13T005444Z_1_LYNXNPEC4C01J_RTROPTP_2_BRAZIL-POLITICS.JPG" width="130" height="86" alt="Brazil&#039;s interim President Michel Temer reatcs during the inauguration ceremony of Gilmar Mendes as the new president of the Superior Electoral Court in Brasilia" align="left" title="Brazil&#039;s interim President Michel Temer reatcs during the inauguration ceremony of Gilmar Mendes as the new president of the Superior Electoral Court in Brasilia" border="0" /></a>By Lisandra Paraguassu and Alonso Soto BRASILIA (Reuters) - Brazil&#039;s interim President Michel Temer called on his country to rally behind his government of &quot;national salvation,&quot;
